definition:
If $f\colon M\rightarrow\mathbf{On}$ is a function from any set of
ordinals to the class of ordinals then
$\operatorname{Fix}(f)=\{x\in M\mid f(x)=x\}$ is the set of fixed points
of $f$. $f^\prime$, the *derivative* of $f$, is the enumerating function
of $\operatorname{Fix}(f)$.

If $f$ is then $\operatorname{Fix}(f)$ is $\kappa$-closed and
$\kappa$-normal, and therefore $f^\prime$ is also $\kappa$-normal.

For example, the function which takes an ordinal $\alpha$ to the ordinal
$1+\alpha$ has a fixed point at every ordinal $\geq\omega$, so
$f^\prime(\alpha)=\omega+\alpha$.
